awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Scientific Computing for Structure in Big or Complex Datasets
awd_abstract_narration:
This project provides for our future generation of effectively trained research scientists. The project anticipates future directions in science by training young scientists in the theoretical and practical use of computation to find, understand, and exploit structure in large or complex data sets. Large and complex data sets are ubiquitous in many areas of science, business and humanities. The project aims to broaden participation in scientific research by locating and encouraging talented students at institutions with fewer research offerings than has the REU site. Along with encouraging a career in science, the project aims to further engage each participant in a lifelong dialog with science and scientific research.

Training, mentorship, presentation, and peer engagement are all key elements addressed by this project to encourage our talented undergraduates to become research scientists. The project provides full scholarships to undergraduates to work with mentors in a ten week summer session on a project from the site's portfolio of projects. The program begins with a science boot camp. Throughout the experience the participants attend lecture series and engage with their cohort of REU participants, further facilitating growth as career scientists. At the conclusion, the participants present their research to their peers and the research community at the site, with some projects selected to be presented at a national conference. 

The portfolio of mentored projects share the theme of computation to find structure in large or complex data sets. Projects feature computation either for the exploration or manipulation of data, such as for visualization or high performance GPU computation, or for the theoretical framework of computation, such as for understanding brain processes, deep learning, and neural nets. Because of the cross-cutting nature of computational science, the projects come from diverse fields with mentors from diverse departments, including Computer Science, Chemistry and Psychology, the Center for Computational Sciences, and the medical school.

por.por_cntn:
The Computing for Structure REU at the University of Miami brought together undergraduate researchers and professor mentors for ten weeks to perform authentic research with the mentor in their labs. Each of three summers, ten undergraduates lived on campus at the university and formed a cohort, shared an initial orientation program, a sequence of ongoing workshops, and worked in labs whose field of science included: computational chemistry, computational science in neural networks, neuron regrowth and neuron damage, tools for the assessment of child behavior development in normal and developmentally challenged situations, and several other labs. The project influences talented and interested undergraduates to pursue research careers.

The unifying principle of the Computing for Structure project is the use of big data and advanced high-performance computing to aid science to achieve its aims. The project unifies the viewpoint that computation is a fundamental tool for science, both to undertake research and as central to the nature of science. Additional goals were the dissemination of learning in computer science to other disciplines, that have become clients of that knowledge.

The goal of the project is to encourage and inform a new generation of scientists. The participants were encouraged through their peer interactions as they come together from diverse backgrounds and diverse educational institutions, and their interactions with the mentors. The institutions ranged from large research universities to small liberal arts colleges. They were informed through boot camp and workshop training in computer science tools and techniques, as well as the specific domain knowledge when they embarked on their mentored project. These young scientists will explore the possibilities of the natural world and solve the vexing problems that confront humanity and the environment.

The mentor projects included several in child behavior at several centers in the Department of Psychology at the University of Miami. Many of the projects investigated the social interaction of children with hearing loss by tracking their movements and eye contact. Also, similar work was done for children with autism. The computational component was to analyze the tracking data and turn it into understandable interaction data. This analysis can be done by hand, but automation will create a much more reliable database for which to draw conclusions.

The mentor projects included several in nerve growth at the Department of Neurology at the University of Miami School of Medicine, associated with the Miami Project to Cure Paralysis. Computational science and learning networks were used to study nerve data to understand growth after various injuries. A project improved tools for the assessment of nerve damage by analysis of task performance by rats.

The mentor projects included several concerning neural networks for vision processing. This work is a research area active in the Department of Computer Science and uses the latest advances in Deep Learning and High-Performance Computing to understand and implement algorithms.

Several projects were in Computational Chemistry, using newly created computer code on GPU clusters to explore new types of environmentally friendly solvents, for use in wet lab work, or in the chemical industry.

Other projects came from mentors with various research programs. One project mathematically analyzed and visualized the sound of musical instruments, for possible applications to musical instrument synthesis. Another project explored public health data, to analyze and visualize factors contributing to diabetes.

All the posters were presented at a public poster session, with speeches and awards. Four posters were presented again at a national science or mathematics conference.
